text: ScRNAseq.jl - for single-cell RNA-seq (scRNAseq) data analysis. Ppl interested in working together, please feel free to contact.

elements.text: ScRNAseq.jl - for single-cell RNA-seq (scRNAseq) data analysis. Ppl interested in working together, please feel free to contact.

text: Sounds interesting! what are your plans for this? Is it to compete with Seurat & Scanpy? i.e. whole ecosystems for scrna-seq analysis? Might be worth building up to this in smaller steps? starting with clustering/DE/etc. There are some good sc analysis packages in julia already for particular tasks to make use of

elements.text: Sounds interesting! what are your plans for this? Is it to compete with Seurat & Scanpy? i.e. whole ecosystems for scrna-seq analysis? Might be worth building up to this in smaller steps? starting with clustering/DE/etc. There are some good sc analysis packages in julia already for particular tasks to make use of

text: one suggestion from my perspective: a particular place where Julia could make a real impact here is speed. As you know current datasets of 10^5 cells cause problems for lots of analysis steps (like tSNE, clustering). Replacing these steps with ML models is gaining popularity - like scVI. Taking such an approach in Julia using the power of Flux for sc analysis tasks could be a real advantage & a way to stand out

text: I'm interested. My first draw to Julia was exactly this: to move scRNA-seq analysis out of scanpy and get a speed up. I'm still very new at Julia, but a project like this would I think be a good backdrop to fuel learning the language

elements.text: I'm interested. My first draw to Julia was exactly this: to move scRNA-seq analysis out of scanpy and get a speed up. I'm still very new at Julia, but a project like this would I think be a good backdrop to fuel learning the language

text: <@ULX1C7GFP> for processing large datasets with tSNE/UMAP have you tried RAPIDS ai's CUML package with GPU accelerated implementations (plus GPU leiden clustering)? It's night and day compared with MulticoreTSNE

elements.text: for processing large datasets with tSNE/UMAP have you tried RAPIDS ai's CUML package with GPU accelerated implementations (plus GPU leiden clustering)? It's night and day compared with MulticoreTSNE

text: <@ULX1C7GFP> <@ULFQVSFJN> i think you both are right. ScRNAseq.jl will have all advantages inherited from JuliaLang itself.

elements.text: i think you both are right. ScRNAseq.jl will have all advantages inherited from JuliaLang itself.

text: I suggest we start from building the most basic framework, instead of considering ScRNAseq.jl as a competitor over Seurat or Scanpy.
